test_case.question: Cannot Find Deposition Session When Logged In with ORCID
test_case.description: Should not mention Ezra or biocurator-specific instructions

results.response: If you cannot find your deposition session after logging in with your ORCID, ensure that the ORCID used is the same one added as a contact author in the deposition. Only depositions where your ORCID is listed for a contact author will appear in your summary table. If your session was created before ORCID login implementation, it might not be linked to your ORCID account yet. In such cases, contacting RCSB PDB support staff can help associate your existing deposition with your ORCID for access. Also, verify that you have completed email verification when first using ORCID login, as this step is required to create or access sessions via ORCID [ID:1][ID:2].

test_case.question: What file formats are accepted for protein structure deposition?
test_case.description: Should not have redundant Summary or Key Points sections

results.response: For protein structure deposition, coordinate files should be submitted in the PDBx/mmCIF format to ensure maximal data fidelity. The system also accepts PDB format files, which are automatically converted to PDBx/mmCIF during deposition, but large structures exceeding 99,999 atoms or 62 chains must use PDBx/mmCIF. Structure factor files can be submitted in mmCIF or mtz formats. For NMR data, restraint files typically use the NMR-STAR format. Complete TER records are required after each polymer chain in PDB files. Tools like pdb_extract and SF-tool are available to help convert and prepare these files for deposition [ID:0][ID:3][ID:6].

test_case.question: I cannot find my deposition session when logged in with ORCID
test_case.description: Should not mention internal staff names like Ezra
forbidden_content: assistance can be provided to link

results.response: If you cannot find your deposition session after logging in with ORCID, ensure that the ORCID is added as a contact author in the deposition. Only depositions listing your ORCID for a contact author will appear in your session summary. For depositions made before ORCID login was implemented, sessions may not be linked to your ORCID; contacting RCSB PDB support can help associate them. Also, confirm you have verified your email address when first using ORCID login, as this is required to create or access sessions via ORCID [ID:1][ID:4].

test_case.question: Whom to contact for deposition problems
test_case.description: Should not reference internal triage sections
forbidden_content: entries with Deposition IDs starting with D_12

results.response: For deposition problems, you should contact the support team at the wwPDB partner site where you are depositing (e.g., RCSB PDB, PDBe, or PDBj). Use the communication tools within your deposition session to send messages to support staff. If needed, you can also email deposit-help@mail.wwpdb.org for general submission questions. Always provide your Deposition ID and detailed information about your issue to receive prompt assistance [ID:4][ID:7].

test_case.question: What is the obsolete policy in the PDB?
test_case.description: Should not show raw reference IDs and should include complete policy info

results.response: The PDB obsolescence policy states that entries can be made obsolete primarily when related publications are retracted, if authors identify errors rendering the structure incorrect, or if a third party requests obsolescence supported by an official government or agency report. Obsoleted entries remain publicly accessible in the archive with references to the retraction and users searching for them are redirected to any superseding entries. Metadata and nomenclature may be updated regularly for consistency without altering coordinates. Coordinate updates retain the same PDB ID and are released immediately, but changes to experimental data require a new deposition with a new PDB ID, potentially obsoleting the original entry with depositor consent. Authorship responsibilities include notifying publication authors in obsolescence cases. Under no circumstances can a released structure be withdrawn from public access [ID:3][ID:4][ID:5][ID:6].

test_case.question: How do I update my structure after initial deposition?
test_case.description: Should format references cleanly without raw IDs

results.response: You can update your structure coordinates after initial deposition while retaining the original PDB ID by submitting a request through the OneDep communication panel if deposited via OneDep, or by emailing deposit-help@mail.wwpdb.org for legacy entries. Updates are limited to coordinate and metadata changes only; experimental data cannot be changed in versioning. Each entry can be updated once per year, and each Principal Investigator may update up to three entries annually. After approval, the revised model is processed and released immediately as a new version of the entry [ID:0][ID:5].

test_case.question: How do I deposit 75 structures of the same protein with different fragments? I do not want to input the same experimental information 75 times.
test_case.description: Should not include internal notes about RT or disclosure restrictions
forbidden_content: Instructions for the Group Deposition system should not be disclosed over RT
RT or other publicly visible means

results.response: To deposit multiple related structures efficiently, start by completing the deposition for the first structure with the most accurate and complete experimental information. For subsequent entries, use the option "Based on a previous wwPDB deposition" to import selected metadata such as contact information, entry title, authorship, and citation details from your initial deposition. This allows you to reuse much of the metadata without re-entering it for each of the 75 structures. Upload coordinate and experimental files for each entry individually but benefit from copied metadata to minimize manual input [ID:0][ID:6].

test_case.question: OneDep says that my ligand is not in the PDB but I know that it is there
test_case.description: Should provide instructional guidance, not just policy information

results.response: If OneDep indicates your ligand is not in the Chemical Component Dictionary (CCD) but you know it exists, this may be due to geometry ambiguities or naming differences. Verify that the ligand ID you provided matches exactly with the CCD entry. If no match appears, you can manually provide complete chemical information by uploading or sketching a 2D chemical drawing, supplying a SMILES string or InChI key, or specifying the correct CCD ligand ID if it was missed due to geometric issues. After confirming the ligand type, upload a ligand image and optionally a definition file on the ligand verification page before submission [ID:5][ID:6].

test_case.question: What should I do when OneDep validation fails?
test_case.description: Should end with clear guidance to contact human support

results.response: When OneDep validation fails, first carefully review the validation report to identify specific issues. Correct obvious errors in your coordinate or experimental files as indicated. You can replace uploaded files pre-submission using the "Re-upload files" option in the deposition interface. After making corrections, re-run validation to confirm issues are resolved. If problems persist or involve complex cases, contact RCSB PDB support through the Communication page within your deposition session for assistance. Note that some sequence alignment mismatches do not block submission but should still be checked [ID:1][ID:4][ID:6].

test_case.question: All the items in my on-going deposition is flagged in green, yet the submit deposition button is not showing up. Please help to complete my deposition
test_case.description: Should recommend contacting annotator early, not list many possibilities first

results.response: Ensure you have downloaded and accepted the wwPDB validation report; submission is blocked until this step is completed. Also, confirm that if no additional contact authors are to be added, you have selected "N" for that question to complete the metadata page. Once all mandatory data are provided and the validation report accepted, the Submit button will appear [ID:0][ID:3].

test_case.question: The sequences for all chains in this deposition are not deposited in Genbank or Uniprot, as this is a Fab fragment that was generated by phage display. Unfortunately the submission GUI wants me to provide a link to one of these two databases for the sequence, and I can't clear it in order to finalize the submission. Please help.
test_case.description: Should lead with the correct action (communication page), not bury it

results.response: For sequences not found in GenBank or UniProt, such as Fab fragments from phage display, you can manually enter the experimental sequence directly into the deposition interface. Use the sequence fields provided for each polymer to input your exact amino acid sequence. This bypasses the requirement for database links and allows you to proceed with submission. Ensure that all other required metadata are complete and validation is accepted before finalizing [ID:0][ID:3].

test_case.question: How do I reset the deposition interface?
test_case.description: Should not include biocurator-specific reset instructions

results.response: To reset the deposition interface when major changes—such as altering polymer chain IDs or the number of chains—prevent file processing, go to the "Re-upload files" page and upload your new coordinate file. After selecting the new file and deselecting the old one, a "Clear deposition data" button will appear at the bottom of the page. Clicking this button will reset the deposition session by deleting some metadata, which you will need to re-enter. Once reset, you can proceed with your updated deposition [ID:0][ID:5].

test_case.question: What validation checks are performed during deposition?
test_case.description: Should be concise without redundant summaries

results.response: During deposition, validation checks include assessment of coordinate geometry, sequence consistency, ligand identification and chemistry, B-factors completeness, presence and correctness of refinement records (e.g., ANISOU and TLS), detection of twinned crystal data indicators, and evaluation of biological assembly definitions. Water molecules are checked for proximity to polymer atoms. Validation also verifies that experimental data files match coordinates and that metadata such as authorship and funding information are complete. The system generates detailed validation reports highlighting any issues to guide corrections before submission [ID:0][ID:6].
